docs.snippet: Two hundred years of tradition cling to the stone fortresses that make up the United States Military Academy here. Cadets awake to reveille and, in their gray uniforms and garrison caps, hurry across campus under lofty monuments to war heroes that...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two hundred years of tradition cling to the stone fortresses that make up the United States Military Academy here. Cadets awake to reveille and, in their gray uniforms and garrison caps, hurry across campus under lofty monuments to war heroes that have developed a layer of verdigris with age. They speak earnestly about a lifetime of selfless service as members of the ''long gray line.'' But as West Point marks its 200th birthday on Saturday, the cadets' world has suddenly, and irrevocably, changed. With a strange new war, with no clear enemy or end, the changes have touched the campus, the curriculum, even the cadets' conception of themselves.
docs.abstract: West Point cadets' world has suddenly, and irrevocably, changed as US Military Academy marks its 200th birthday; with strange new war, with no clear enemy or end, changes have touched campus, curriculum, even cadets' conception of themselves; few graduates have already died in war in Afghanistan, and four senior faculty members were sent there to serve on planning staff; National Guardsmen with M-16's now man West Point's gates, and tourists are allowed on campus only with official tour groups; administation is updating battle drills by putting civilians on field, and as exercise in diplomacy, cadets must answer questions from mock reporters; course on terrorism is new; some cadets comment; photo (M)

headline.main: For a Bastion Of Tradition, A New World; Events of Sept. 11 Altered West Point, Too

docs.snippet: ATKINSON-Clinton J. 74, died suddenly on March 4, in his summer home in Craryville, NY. He was in high spirits-and then he left us, a good death for him, difficult for family and friends. Clint was a professional theater director, at Long Island S...
docs.lead_paragraph: ATKINSON-Clinton J. 74, died suddenly on March 4, in his summer home in Craryville, NY. He was in high spirits-and then he left us, a good death for him, difficult for family and friends. Clint was a professional theater director, at Long Island Stage and many other theaters, the latest, New York State Theater in Albany. He taught drama at Vassar, Wesleyan, SUNY Albany. He was born and raised in the Canal Zone, Panama, educated at William and Mary, and Yale, and was a lieutenant in the Korean War. His beloved family-wife Lois, sons Matthew and Seth, daughters-in-law Wendy and Oak, grandsons Blake and Kirk-feel blessed by having had this unique man and mind in their lives, a bibliophile, host, jam maker, mensch. A memorial service in NYC will be announced later. Donations would be appreciated to Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave, PO Box 56322, Montgomery, AL 36177-7459.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKINSON, CLINTON J.

docs.lead_paragraph: Walter Fuld Gips Jr., a retired electronics industry executive and former treasurer of the American Jewish Committee, died Sunday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 81. The cause was complications from colon cancer and diabetes, according to his family.
docs.abstract: Walter Fuld Gips Jr, retired electronics industry executive and former treasurer of American Jewish Committee, dies at age 81 (S)

docs.snippet: FLIEGEL-Norris E., Ed.D. World War II veteran, Dr. Fleigel trained in psychoanalysis at Clark University in Worcester, MA, graduate of Harvard and NYU, former Dean of The School of Education and former Vice Chancellor of Hunter College, co-author ...
docs.lead_paragraph: FLIEGEL-Norris E., Ed.D. World War II veteran, Dr. Fleigel trained in psychoanalysis at Clark University in Worcester, MA, graduate of Harvard and NYU, former Dean of The School of Education and former Vice Chancellor of Hunter College, co-author with the late Bernard Rosenberg of ''The Vanguard Artist.'' Also maintained a private practice in psychology throughout his life. Beloved husband of the late Zenia, dear brother of Roslyn Tanzer and Burton, brother-in-law of Louis and Susan. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Services private. FLIEGEL-Norris. Board of Directors of 37 Apartments Corporation wishes to express their heartfelt sympathy for the passing of Board Member and past President of the Board Norris Fliegel. Sincere thanks to Norris for all of his effort and concern for the building.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLIEGEL, NORRIS E., ED.D.

docs.snippet: Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, became so concerned last week that tensions over Kashmir would spill into war with India that he telephoned the American ambassador in Islamabad, Wendy J. Chamberlin, to ask where Washington intended to...
docs.lead_paragraph: Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, became so concerned last week that tensions over Kashmir would spill into war with India that he telephoned the American ambassador in Islamabad, Wendy J. Chamberlin, to ask where Washington intended to draw the line in supporting India. ''What General Musharraf wanted to know was how Washington could guarantee that India wouldn't wait for some new incident to occur, then claim that it was backed by Pakistan and use it as a pretext to go to war,'' an aide to the general said, insisting on anonymity. ''The general's reasoning was: 'What if some outraged Kashmiri takes a Kalashnikov and shoots an Indian politician or puts a bomb in a parking lot? Is Pakistan going to be held accountable every time anybody picks up a weapon? Is Washington saying that all freedom struggles, everywhere, can be suppressed under the guise of the war on terrorism?' ''

docs.snippet: You need a California workout to lift ''Case Study Houses: The Complete CSH Program 1946-66'' (Taschen; $105), by Elizabeth Smith, but the book, an exhaustive homage to the houses, is worth the effort. The experimental homes were built after World...
docs.lead_paragraph: You need a California workout to lift ''Case Study Houses: The Complete CSH Program 1946-66'' (Taschen; $105), by Elizabeth Smith, but the book, an exhaustive homage to the houses, is worth the effort. The experimental homes were built after World War II as prototypes for mass housing. The book has pictures and plans by the Eamses, Richard Neutra, Eero Saarinen and others. Pierre Koenig's Case Study 22 in West Hollywood for Carlotta and Buck Stahl is still used in fashion shoots and in movies, like ''Nurse Betty.' Principal photography by (who else?) Julius Shulman.
docs.abstract: Case Study Houses: The Complete CSH Program, 1946-66, book by Elizabeth Smith, chronicles experimental homes built after World War II as prototypes for mass housing; photo (S)

headline.main: A Guide to an Experiment In Housing Weighs In

docs.snippet: In a case that has alternately haunted and humiliated the Justice Department for more than two decades, a federal judge today revoked the United States citizenship of John Demjanjuk, an 81-year-old retired Cleveland auto worker who prosecutors cha...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a case that has alternately haunted and humiliated the Justice Department for more than two decades, a federal judge today revoked the United States citizenship of John Demjanjuk, an 81-year-old retired Cleveland auto worker who prosecutors charged was a Nazi death camp guard in World War II. The judge, Paul R. Matia of Federal District Court in Cleveland, ruled that Mr. Demjanjuk knowingly misrepresented his past when he entered the United States in 1952. At the time, Mr. Demjanjuk, a native of Ukraine, said he had had served in the Soviet army until he was captured by German forces and spent much of the war in prison camps.

headline.main: Demjanjuk Loses Citizenship Again; Judge Cites Lies

docs.snippet: Washington is filled with excited talk these days about the transforming role of America's Special Operations forces in Afghanistan. While it is true that these elite units, along with C.I.A. operatives, contributed effectively to the swift victor...
docs.lead_paragraph: Washington is filled with excited talk these days about the transforming role of America's Special Operations forces in Afghanistan. While it is true that these elite units, along with C.I.A. operatives, contributed effectively to the swift victory over the Taliban, the circumstances in Afghanistan are unlikely to be duplicated in many other wars. There is good reason to strengthen unconventional forces and to look for opportunities to use them in future conflicts, especially in other fronts in the war against terrorism, but the Bush administration should not assume that the campaign in Afghanistan has revolutionized modern warfare. In Afghanistan, small numbers of the Pentagon's Special Operations forces worked closely with C.I.A. officers to organize offensive operations by the Northern Alliance and other opposition groups and to direct the American airstrikes that shattered the Taliban army. The success of these operations made it unnecessary to send in the large numbers of American ground troops the Pentagon once feared would be necessary.
docs.abstract: Editorial discusses outlook for America's Special Operations forces in light of important and transforming role they played in war against terrorism in Afghanistan; says there is good reason to strengthen unconventional forces and to look for opportunities to use them in future conflicts, especially in other fronts in war against terrorism, but cautions Bush administration against assuming that campaign in Afghanistan has revolutionized modern warfare
